title: How long will Mass. residents have to wait until their power is restored?
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Over 220,000 Eversource customers in Eastern Massachusetts remain without power following Monday's blizzard.
National Grid aims for full power restoration by Wednesday midnight, but some may wait until Thursday.
High winds and blizzard conditions delayed power restoration efforts across Cape Cod and the Islands.

title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots possess 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, including the 31st overall in the first round.
Top prospects for Patriots include WR KC Concepcion, Edge Zion Young, and TE Kenyon Sadiq for roster upgrades.
The NFL Combine in Indianapolis is key for evaluating over 300 draft prospects through drills, interviews, and measurements.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A Malden school employee is on leave after an alleged incident involving a high school student.
Malden police are investigating the incident, which reportedly happened outside of working hours.
No arrests or charges have been made, and the employee worked at Linden School.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Massachusetts schools on the South Coast and South Shore are mostly closed on Wednesday due to a historic snowstorm.
The storm resulted in three feet of snow in parts of Massachusetts, leading to closures for safety and cleanup.
Schools like Attleboro, Brockton, and Silver Lake are closed, while others like Canton and Sharon have delayed openings.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: MBTA to resume regular service Wednesday after snowstorm, except Fall River/New Bedford line with modified schedule.
MBTA General Manager thanked employees and riders for patience and efforts during storm recovery.
Keolis Commuter Services advises extra travel time and caution on platforms due to ongoing storm cleanup.

title: Curran: Patriots could ‘explore options’ to potentially upgrade from Stefon Diggs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots consider upgrading from Stefon Diggs due to high 2026 cap hit and need for a younger roster.
Diggs' contract has a $26.5 million cap hit with options for restructuring or exploring alternatives.
Legal issues and age further complicate Diggs' future with the Patriots, who may seek cheaper options.

title: Mass. representatives, including minority whip, to skip State of the Union address
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Massachusetts representatives, including House Minority Whip Katherine Clark, will skip the State of the Union address in protest.
Rep. Ayanna Pressley and others focus on immigrant rights, with Pressley attending the 'People’s State of the Union' rally.
Sen. Ed Markey criticizes Trump, opting for a rally over attending the address, emphasizing the need for reality and accountability.

title: Will Charlie McAvoy, Jeremy Swayman be back in Bruins lineup when they resume play Thursday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman's return to the Bruins remains uncertain ahead of Thursday's game against Columbus.
McAvoy and Swayman helped Team USA win Olympic gold and attended events in Miami and Washington, D.C.
The Bruins hold the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, leading Columbus by four points before their matchup.

title: Could Trent Williams suddenly emerge as a free-agent target for Patriots?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Trent Williams is in a contract standoff with the 49ers, possibly entering the 2026 free-agent market.
The Patriots could target Trent Williams to improve their offensive line, addressing key positional needs.
Williams, aged 37, earned third-highest PFF grade for tackles in 2025, though he will require significant investment.

title: Boston ends snow emergency parking ban; residents can use space savers until Thursday evening
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston's snow emergency and parking ban ended at 6 p.m. Tuesday after a blizzard dropped 17 inches of snow.
Residents must remove space savers by 6 p.m. Thursday or face removal by the city's Public Works Department.
Citywide snow removal efforts continue, with 165 loads totaling 4,620 cubic yards cleared overnight, according to Mayor Wu.
